messages.author: sadrul
messages.text: I am thinking this should be a DCHECK.

messages.author: stevenjb
messages.text:
On 2012/05/15 15:10:50, sadrul wrote:
> I am thinking this should be a DCHECK.

I would rather keep this safe in case a class calls this without checking that its detailed view is open. It should really be an early exit though, I'll fix that.

messages.author: sadrul
messages.text: OVERRIDE shouldn't be in its own line. You can move the parameter from the line before (see tray_power)

messages.author: sadrul
messages.text: This is OK. But I wanted to point out that the rest of the tray-related code has these in a tray:: namespace.

messages.author: stevenjb
messages.text:
On 2012/05/15 15:10:50, sadrul wrote:
> OVERRIDE shouldn't be in its own line. You can move the parameter from the line
> before (see tray_power)

Done.

messages.author: stevenjb
messages.text:
On 2012/05/15 15:10:50, sadrul wrote:
> This is OK. But I wanted to point out that the rest of the tray-related code has
> these in a tray:: namespace.

That works fine too, but in this case most of these also need to be friends, so this is more compact.

messages.author: sadrul
messages.text: Just to clarify, this is one row in a detailed/notification view?

messages.author: sadrul
messages.text: It looks like the detailed view gets a close button, but the notification button doesn't. Is that intentional? Should TrayNotificationView be involved somehow?

messages.author: stevenjb
messages.text:
On 2012/05/15 15:10:50, sadrul wrote:
> Just to clarify, this is one row in a detailed/notification view?
Correct.

messages.author: stevenjb
messages.text:
On 2012/05/15 15:10:50, sadrul wrote:
> It looks like the detailed view gets a close button, but the notification button
> doesn't. Is that intentional? Should TrayNotificationView be involved somehow?

SmsNotificationView inherits a close button from TrayNotificationView. 
The detailed entries also need a close button, but the layout is a little different. 
I could do this as a base class and two subclasses if that would be more readable?
